abstract.p: Yale University's endowment rose 40 percent in year ended June 30, to $10 billion; university's chief investment adviser David Swensen sold millions of dollars of American stocks in 1990's and bet on private equity and venture capital funds; Harvard University's endowment fund, which took different path, returned 32.2 percent in same period (S)

block.p: Throughout the 1990's, pension funds and university endowments added to their domestic stock holdings to take advantage of the bull market. Not Yale University.
In the last decade, Yale sold hundreds of millions of dollars of American stocks. The equities it did buy tended to be value and small-cap stocks, which have been depressed in recent years.
Throughout the 1990's, pension funds and university endowments added to their domestic stock holdings to take advantage of the bull market. Not Yale University.
In the last decade, Yale sold hundreds of millions of dollars of American stocks. The equities it did buy tended to be value and small-cap stocks, which have been depressed in recent years.
Yet Yale has come out ahead because the university's chief investment adviser, David Swensen, bet on private equity, hedge and venture capital funds.
The endowment rose 40 percent in the year ended June 30, to $10 billion. Harvard University's endowment fund returned 32.2 percent during the same period.
''We've done things differently from the institutional orthodoxy,'' Mr. Swensen said in a recent interview with Bloomberg News.

Just 25 percent of Yale's money is in plain-vanilla American stocks and bonds, compared with the typical university allocation of 75 percent reported by the National Association of College and University Business Officers.
